members.name: Jenny Hane
members.bio: I'm an Electrical Engineer who joined the industry in 2012.  My day job has me working for SEAKR Engineering as an FPGA designer, with a little DSP thrown in.  In my spare time I dabble in robotics, so FIRST mentoring was a natural fit.

members.name: Sherry Garfio
members.bio: I'm an electrical engineer with a background in physics.  For the past 3 years I have worked at SEAKR Engineering Inc. doing FPGA design for spacecraft avionics systems.  In my spare time I enjoy rock climbing, backpacking, and DIY electronics.

members.name: Marty Otzenberger
members.bio: I'm an electrical engineer with a background in physics.  For the past 3 years I have worked at SEAKR Engineering Inc. doing FPGA design for spacecraft avionics systems.  In my spare time I enjoy rock climbing, backpacking, and DIY electronics.

members.name: Corey Kesler
members.bio: I teach physics at Eaglecrest High School and love helping students put science and technology lessons into action.

members.name: Guy Stone
members.bio: Being a FIRST mentor is an incredibly rewarding experience for me, and I am continually inspired by the hard work and dedication that I see in the team members. As a mentor, I try to encourage team members to embrace non-conventional strategies and designs. One of the biggest traps that a team can fall in to is to keep recycling the same ideas and designs year after year because it is something they are comfortable with, or because they have seen other teams doing something similar. The best teams challenge themselves to come up with innovative designs to play the game each year, and I believe it is the role of the mentors to use their experience to help the team work through the details and bang out a functioning robot that achieves those design goals within six weeks. It is a (not so) secret goal of mine to win a regional with a robot that can't move, because that would be awesome, and it would be a nice little poke in the eye to all of the teams that spend so much time inventing fancy drive systems.

members.name: Ken Stich
members.bio: I'm a jack-of-all-trades, have degrees in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, so robotics is really fun as it involves so many aspects of engineering.  And of course, it's fun working with students to solve problems.
